Dialogue: EXT. MANHATTAN - NIGHT

Speaker: rookie cop
Dialogue: Cooool.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Evening, Constable!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Are you familiar with the expression `I can explain everything'?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Terribly sorry, but in the film they used a different model to show the old Batchap getting in and out. This one has no doors, so I'd have to squeeze out the back arsehole first. Which nobody wants...  It's a joke! Okay, okay.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Well. What with having spunked 1.6 million fat Alberts on this little runaround, I thought why not take it a step further and try to actually collar a few ne-er do wells? It worked for the billionaire Bruce Wayne, why not the future billionaire Arthur Bach- Templemead? Will I have to do traffic school?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: To use the technical medical term - megabloodyshitloads. Either that or I've had a stroke! But fret not, I have a designated driver.

Speaker: homeless robin
Dialogue: Where's my five thousand dollars?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: The Boy Homeless here neglected to say he'd never driven.

Speaker: homeless robin
Dialogue: It's LIZARDS! English prick!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I trust this will cover all repairs to New York and any inconvenience to your good selves?

Speaker: jay
Dialogue: Then the crazy motherfucker cut me!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Goodness. Why?

Speaker: jay
Dialogue: Said I cut the bombita with pig killer!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Rude man. And who threw hot Americano in whose face again?

Speaker: jay
Dialogue: I did in his. No half and half neither. That shit burnt!

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: I burnt my sister's hair.

Speaker: jay
Dialogue: Cool...

Speaker: gary
Dialogue: Ho wanted to evict me, just 'cause I don't fit her definition of hygiene. Plenty of places to take a shit, toilet's just one of them. Just ask the a-rabs.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's like a chat show, this.  Carmella, when did you first dream of becoming a crack whore?

Speaker: prostitute
Dialogue: Mother died when I was six.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Oh G-d, I hate when that happens.

Speaker: prostitute
Dialogue: My father raped me when I was twelve.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sounds like you had six relatively good years.

Speaker: jay
Dialogue: What do you do?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I model riding boots, I spend money, I sleep with women. But I have weekends off and I am my own boss.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I never thought New York's underbelly could be quite such agreeable company. I shall never forget you. Farewell.

Speaker: devere
Dialogue: I don't think your mother will be pleased, Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Really, Elverton - if a chap can't help out a few chums, whatever their station in life.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I am the Batman. Gotham can sleep easy tonight.

Speaker: jay
Dialogue: Don't point that shit at me, bitch! I will FUCK YOU UP!

Speaker: homeless robin
Dialogue: Yes! Yes! Kill the lizards!

Speaker: press
Dialogue: Arthur! What will your mother say? Didn't she send you here to get you out of the British papers? Arthur!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Anyone need a job? My last driver resigned after I filled his limo with squirrels. Preferably sober, clean driving licence?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Stand back!

Speaker: carmella
Dialogue: Oh, man. Nobody tell you about the recession?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: The what?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Roll up, roll up, folks, let's fix this thing right now.  How much, sir?

Speaker: first man
Dialogue: Um. $800 please.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Coming right up.  Fries with that?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Pierre! We'd like 182 pate de foie gras, 182 chateaubriand steaks, a motherlode of chips and your entire wine cellar please.

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Arthur?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Are you familiar with the expression `I can't explain anything'?

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Who are the women with you, Arthur?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Oh, um, this is Sofia. I believe she works for Avis. Checks the cars for dings, dead people in the trunk, that sort of thing. And this is Carmella. Anyway...

Speaker: erica's father
Dialogue: What do you do, Carmella?

Speaker: carmella
Dialogue: Whatever you want. But no penetration without a rubber.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Carmella's joking. She's actually a...queen. Of a very small country.

Speaker: erica's father
Dialogue: Is she now?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's terribly small.

Speaker: erica's father
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Rhode Island could beat the crap out of it in a war.

Speaker: erica's father
Dialogue: Yes, it's a small place.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: 85 cents in a cab from one end of the country to the other. I'm talking small.

Speaker: erica's father
Dialogue: I think I understand how small it is.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Just had the entire country carpeted, this is not a big place.

Speaker: erica's father
Dialogue: You need to grow up, Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: That's easy for you to say, you haven't got 50 pairs of short trousers hanging in your closet. Maybe we should go somewhere else.

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Maybe you should.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Could I have all those lobsters to go, please?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Cup of tea? Nice hot cup of hot Rosy Lee right up your fanny?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hugh Grant Mr Bean self deprecation mad cow disease Yorkshire pudding bad teeth rain rain rain rain!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Morning, Hobson!

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Morning, Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Umm...Celebration of Kwanzaa.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: The African heritage festival celebrated five months from now?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Why are you stopping? Oh, sorry. How impolite of me. Sofia, this is Hobson, my nanny.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: Nanny?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: He's merely shaped like an adult.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: Is she going to stay here?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hobson, could you come back in a minute and a half please?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Negative. You're seeing your mother this morning.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Nobody told me.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Actually I did, on the other side of the vast moat of champagne known as `last night'.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hobson! Really...

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I had to dab Tabasco sauce on the nipples to see him off...

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: I can't do this.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I support your decision 100%. Will you be requiring a taxi, or just be getting in a random passing car?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Cancel my mother please, Hobson. I'll work from bed today.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Aren't you a fan of Carcass?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: OKAY, OKAY, I'LL GET UP!

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Good boy.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm going for a shower.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I'll alert the media.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: To Bombay, a travelling circus came...

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: They brought an intelligent elephant and Nellie was her name...Hobson!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Female Tom Hanks!

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: She's early today...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Can we invite her up and dress her as Forrest Gump?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Just for a laugh! We'll pay her.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Do your armpits.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: That reminds me, clean your genitals. Heaven knows what wildlife that girl was harbouring between her thighs.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I give you `Sideways farting spider'.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Arthur, you have to stop giving money away!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm a philanthropist.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: With the emphasis on the `pissed'. Really, what is it about unearned wealth that brings out such idiocy in those who have it and those who want it? The way you're going, you'll have spent your inheritance before you've inherited it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: `Eagle pointing at lesbian.'

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Why did you fire Jessica?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What kind of yoga teacher won't let a pupil invent positions? She was a Nazi with a pan pipe C.D.  `Upwards Pooping Astronaut'.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Interesting. It looks more like `Rich twit hiding from mother.' May I remind you, she finances your preposterous existence...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I know, I know. Never bite the hand that fists me.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Sorry, fellas.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: You don't seriously intend to keep employing this gentleman?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Give the guy a chance, Hobson. He got laid off in Chicago...

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: But he doesn't know his way around New York!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: So? I want interesting, fun people around me, not drones who just get the job done...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: ...and inspired by the machine age of the 1920s, this magnificent structure was the world's tallest building for 11 months before the Empire State stole its thunder.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: 1047 feet madam, not allowing for pigeon shit. Okay, let's cross.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Can I join your tour please?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Sure. It's $15, plus $5 for the free authentic street pretzel. Sorry, my bosses make the prices.

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: !NO ME HINCHAN LAS PELOTAS!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: PEGUELO ENCIMA DE SU ASNO, USTED PINCHAZO GRANDE SU MADRE ES UN PUTA ENORMA Y SU PADRE NO TIENE NINGUIN MARTILLO!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Wow. What did you say?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Just generalised criticism of his parents and genitals.  Sir? What shape is Times Square?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: A circle?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: See? Morons.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Soon, sir. Soon.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: ...Mr Big from Sex and the City and three of the 9-11 terrorists.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Are you abusing this tour to do your errands?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Are you abusing the tour to stalk me?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Absolutely.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Where the blazes is that boy? Arthur!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Ahead, the jewel in Manhattan's crown, the Empire State Building. This iconic symbol of American corporate might was adapted during World War 2 in case of attack from enemy forces. At three minutes' notice the entire structure can retract into the ground like a tortoise's head.

Speaker: tourist
Dialogue: That's not possible. I should know, I'm a civil engineer.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You're not being very civil to me.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: The building doesn't retract; the ground rises up.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Exactly. The ground rises up! Thank you, sir.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: They were going to install giant legs so if a plane was flying at the tower it could run away. But where's it going to run?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Manhattan's in the way.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It'd have to jump in the Hudson.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Victory to the Nazis. Is that what you want?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: If you go on Perez Hilton or TMZ.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: What are they?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: The gossip websites.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: That the internet? Ah, my computer's too old for all that.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: For the internet? Seriously?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Life's too short for all this obsessive upgrading.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You consider the internet an upgrade? Wow.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: So why do people gossip about you?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Ah, that was a joke. I'm nobody.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: You're late for your mother!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: The soup kitchen's just up and to the left, honey.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hobson, this is...  Naomi.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: She's with you?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Delighted to meet you, Naomi. Normally one has to go to a bowling alley to meet a woman of your stature.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Ooh, Grandma's got jokes.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: You aren't the first woman who walks the streets this young man has asked.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Who's this? Joan Rivers' older bitterer sister?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: My nanny.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Obviously. Seriously, who is she?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: My nanny. Well, she started as that, but these days she's more of an all-round enforcer and bodyguard.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Sorry, I have to get out the cattle prod and haul ass. Got another tour starting in eight minutes.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Can I call you?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I don't give my number to grown men with nannies. But as you may not be

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: But what if this is the one?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: This is just like the Komodo dragon. Everyone else is happy to see one in the zoo and leave it there. You had to own one. Thank goodness that handbag manufacturer was prepared to take the poor lizard away.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You said he's in London Zoo!

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: He is, Arthur. Are you the only one allowed to joke now?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I don't like it here.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Of course you don't. People work here.

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: Good afternoon, Mr Bach-Templemead.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hi Grant. Tell me - which of your parents are you most like? Abercrombie or Fitch?

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: I have no connection with that store. My family name is Von Krausehoff. Take a seat please.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Don't fret, Arthur. This won't take long. Then we'll have ice cream.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Vivienne.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: You know I prefer `mother'.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm sorry. You look more like a Vivienne.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: So. How are you, Arthur?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Quite busy. I have a riding boot shoot for Petrie Dressage...

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Did I hear you say you were meeting Ivanka Trump for brunch? That's nice. Right. Today we're going to have a friendly chat. Then a serious talk. And lastly make a timetable. How does all that sound?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Amazing. Do you have any vodka?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: What happened, Arthur? You were such a sweet baby.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I still wake up in my own poo occasionally.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Right, that's it for the chat. Time to transition to our talk.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Can't Hobson set them aside for me?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Susan is a splendid girl. Her feet are on the ground, she's of fine stock...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Oh. That's what this is all about. I'm not marrying Susan. I don't love her.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: And? You think I spent my marriage to your father skipping through meadows?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Not after you ran him over in the Bentley, no. Susan's boring. She's not funny.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Ditto your father. The aristocracy doesn't marry for `fun', Arthur. It's about stability. Continuity...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: ...and sinking your fangs into Susan's father's bank account.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: The Johnson family's considerable equity in a stormy financial period is merely a side issue. Burt is a pillar of the community.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: His baby formula was taken off the market in six African countries!

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: A completely innocent error in places where there's precious little for children to live for anyway. The families all got gift baskets as compensation. That little bump in the road aside, Burt is a devout Christian.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Yes, because they're never insane. And where did he get Jesus?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Burt paid his debt to society years ago.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: He strangled a fireman! Who strangles a fireman?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Arthur...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Vivienne. I've met someone else very lovely who, as far as I know, isn't related to anyone who would kill an unsung hero in cold blood.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Un-meet her. Arthur, you're the end of our line. We need an heir.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I nearly gave you an heir!

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Oh, give me strength! A Bach- Templemead having a child by a lap dancer called `Mystery'?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: That was just her stage name! To give her more mystery when she...waved her fanny around. Her real name was...what was it again?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Susan is 33 this year. Her egg inventory has dropped by 23% since you met her. You risk having no sons, or worse, some pea-brained hunchback who hugs everyone!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Great! I like hugs! And some of them are really good at math.  You know the `Frog and Toad' books?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Of course you don't. Hobson read them to me while you were off riding horses over stripey poles. They're about fun and friendship, not how many unspasticated tadpoles I can squirt up a rich girl.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Your father would turn in his grave to hear this nonsense...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: That I won't follow in his footsteps and marry a woman I hate? I think he might climb out of the grave and dance on it.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Suit yourself.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You wouldn't! You're my...

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: ...Vivienne? Try me.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Ah. The ring your father gave your mother, I recall.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Did he knock her out with it, then drive her to the church in the trunk of his Bentley?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: No. Your father was a gentleman.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What's gentlemanly about dying before I knew him? That's just rude. Did he ever love my mother?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: They had their days.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Ah well. At least he doesn't have to wake up every day to a woman with a face like saran wrap stretched over a gargoyle.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Arthur. I say this with love:

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Uh-oh...

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Even by modern male standards you're a breathtakingly immature little shit. Coupled with the kind of money you have access to, that's deadly. Susan may not have a four hour stand up routine about the Flatiron Building, but she's a solid girl who will look after you.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I have you for that.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Not forever.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Yes forever. You're Hobson.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Hello?  Hello?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Oh, hi! What's up?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I've never really understood that question. Are you free tomorrow night?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Sorry, I'm polishing my yacht.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Is that a euphemism for something naughty?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: No, it's a lie. I have a creative writing class. Tonight?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I have a contractual commitment. Friday?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You got it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Paper.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Sorry?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sorry, I was talking to something else. So. What do you want to do?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: A movie?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Movie? Come on, you've got to try harder than that.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Pizza.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What have you always wanted to do?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: It's a first date, Arthur. Not our honeymoon.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Every date will be our honeymoon.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Ewww. Okay, uh, picnic in the park...or dinner with a view. I like views.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What sort of food do you like?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Anything but guts and mushrooms. Okay, enough questions.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Oh come on. This all helps build up a profile of you before I trick you into my basement. I'd hate to not have your favourite snacks ready.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Turkey Jerky and Pez. Are we done? Just that I....

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Time to get engaged, Arthur. The Komodo dragon can wait.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hi! Is it June 19th at 7 pm?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: FUCK! We overshot! Time travel can be a real cunt sometimes, don't you think? I'll be right back. See you in an hour and a half ago...

Speaker: butler
Dialogue: Would you care for anything while you wait?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: A trampoline and a selection of woodland creatures if that's not too much trouble.

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: Arthur!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I, er, had a bit of food stuck in my teeth and couldn't find a toothpick.

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: Heck, this sword went through three crusades. Beheaded 1000 moslems. Nothing you can do to harm it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You don't, um, have anything stronger, do you?

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: Sparkling.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Surely a glass of sherry at Christmas?

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: Peace be with you.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: And also with me.

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: Arthur. Can I be honest with you?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You're the real Slim Shady? I knew it!

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: My faith teaches me to hate the sin, not the sinner. But with you, I struggle with that belief.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You could switch to Judaism.  Bit warm in here. Do you mind if I put the fan on?

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: Anyway, Arthur. However I feel about you, my daughter loves you.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Yes, it's a problem, isn't it?

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: You made love to a guy?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: One Moslem doesn't make a mosque, Burt.

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: You made love to a Moslem?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: No, sir, it was Prince Alois of Lichtenstein and he made love to me. The fact that it took three bottles of poppers and a Jacuzzi full of Krug to loosen me up confirmed my heterosexuality.

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: `If there is a man who lies with a male, they shall surely be put to death.'

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Crikey. Couldn't there just be some kind of on-the-spot fine?

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: You will stop this talk and marry - my - fucking...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Oh bollocks.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Sorry to make you wait, Arthur. I was talking to your mother. I hear you have something to ask me!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Shall we go?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Do you have something with less words please? The chef doesn't have to re-cook it, just scrape off the nouns and trim out all that gibberish in the middle.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: He's just joshing, Dominic. I'll do the skate in wood ear mushroom.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Excellent decision. Sir?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: A bowl of champagne and a spoon.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Arthur, did you really have to be so icky to Dominic?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I just can't handle the whole specials act. It's not a Shakespearean soliloquy, it's some heated up dead things that aren't on the main menu.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: You know, I was grumbling to your mother about how things are with us sometimes. How I'm sure you're trying to drive me away...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Um hm.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: But she was explaining that relationships are like property purchases; invest only in high-end stock, avoid anyone 'up-and- coming', then hold onto the property through thick and thin to deliver maximum return! Isn't that darling?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Is it possible to buy the house but then rent it out? Sorry, joke. I'm not suggesting pimping you.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Arthur. Why can't you learn to laugh at genuinely amusing things?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Such as?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: YouTube clips of babies giggling. Dane Cook.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Susan. Why are we together?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I love you, Arthur. And you love me, whatever you think.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: We don't have the same sense of humour. We don't like the same films, food, music. You like horses, I think they're arrogant idiots...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Don't they say opposites attract?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: That depends on the opposites. Racists and the Nation of Islam don't secretly want to 69 each other. Susan, you're beautiful. You're bright. You're fucking loaded. Is there really no one else who could make you happy?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Never?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Well, I had a thing at college. That was serious for a while. But daddy...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Daddy what? Prayed to Jesus for it not to work out, then shot the bloke behind a meat truck? Because Jesus would consider that cheating.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Ask me, Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Susan. You're the only woman...at this table.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: You're not happy, Arthur. Nobody who drinks like you can be happy.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: How do you know? What if the drunker I get the better it is for me? Not everyone who drinks is a poet, Susan. Some of us drink because we're not poets.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: A real woman could stop you from drinking.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It'd have to be a real big woman.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Ask me, Arthur.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Yes, I'll marry you.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Ladies and gentleman - the happy couple!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Erica will be the planner.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Erica? She hates me.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Who I love, she loves.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Oh, come on. She always looks like she wants to set fire to my face then put it out with an Uzi.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Hello...thanks, daddy! Sorry, hang on, I have Erica calling...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What's going on? I only just bloody proposed!

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: And stop this self-pitying bibble. You're going to be fabulously rich.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Maybe I'd rather be fabulously poor. Some poor people I see look happy.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: That's either because they're far away or you've just given them money. Arthur, poor people have to work. They stand for hours in the rain, waiting for buses full of other poor people to take them to things called `jobs' which they do all year round to pay for holidays away from those jobs.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Don't patronise me. I have a job.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Lying drunk on a bale of hay in riding boots being photographed by another pampered prick won't prepare you for the work I mean. And I don't want to see you suffer. Take your fish oil.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: When are we getting cable?

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Honey, that's some bullshit aerial from the 99 cent Store!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: It's a satellite dish!

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: I read the box! It said `No satellite fees to pay because does not receive satellite signals!' That's like saying `Hey - eat this plate of broken glass! It won't make you fat. 'cause IT'S GLASS!'

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: It's better than nothing.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: No it ain't. Honey, I love you, but you're even cheaper than your mom. And she bought food from yard sales.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I miss her too, daddy. But now she's gone and if I'm going to keep you in grits and Oprah the rest of your life, you live by my rules.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: But you live like you're preparing for a war. And you earn a decent salary.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: So? I want to know I can look after you.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: What's he do, this English bum?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Who cares? He's nice. He's funny.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Yeah and I bet that girl said the same about her date. Honey, stay home. I don't want you ending up like that poor girl.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: A bad actress holding her breath?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Can you put this on please?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: On a first date? Are you crazy?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Trust me.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Arthur. We're in Battery Park at night. I've met you once - in the company of your nanny. You make a disturbing number of jokes about stalking and basements. My dad already has you down as a mass murderer. And you want me to put on a blindfold?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I give you my word - if I kill and eat you, you'll never see me again.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Okay, I'm officially a little worried.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Don't worry!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Arthur, I don't know what to say. It's beautiful.  Who did all this?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: The picnic fairies. Who liaised with the flower fairies, the candle fairies, the log fire fairies, the hidden sound system fairies...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Did you take account of the heroin fairies who hang here at night?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's nice to keep it simple like this. I'm sick of Michelin-star restaurants. All that embarrassing crap with the specials.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Are you kidding? Where I normally eat, the special's the one that comes with a free toy.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I get by.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: `It doesn't remotely matter how much or what you spend it on' rich?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I once inadvertently financed a terrorist cell who said they needed 100,000 to open a falafel stall.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Oh my G-d, you're serious.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What's the craziest thing you ever told a tour party?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I once said the Manhattan we were in was actually a movie set built for `You've got Mail', but that after the film wrapped, everyone moved to the set because there was less crime.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sounds like you're very good to him.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: What are you gonna do? All those years your folks tucked you in, did their best to stop you from eating crap in front of the TV. And then one day, you're the one saying `No, honey, it's bad for you! Go to bed.' Weird, huh?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Nice bit of kitsch. Where did you find that?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's...You've had it twelve years?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: It's a fine phone. Battery life of eleven seconds, which cuts the crap right out of conversations.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I couldn't decide between picnic in the park and dinner with a view. So it's a picnic in the sky! Isn't it ace?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: No it is not ace, you crazy English bastard! This is dangerous!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Oh, sorry. Forgot. They said to put these on.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You're seriously making date small talk while this is going on?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Be still. Breathe deep.  `When you can be calm in the midst of activity, this is the true state of nature': Huanchu Daoeren.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: `Lower this freak show to the ground and get me a cab': Naomi Snart.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Taste this truffle.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: What the hell. Gotta go sometime, right? At least it won't be years of pain like mom. Just a few seconds of screaming and falling with a truffle in my mouth.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: So anyway. The tours...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Okay, okay. Be deep. Breathe still. The tours are a temporary nine year fill-in until I'm drowned in a tsunami of apologies from everyone who failed to recognise my writing genius first time round.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What did you write?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: A kids' book. I sent a chapter to a childrens' publisher. Sunshine Press'. The rejection letter was the meanest thing I ever read.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Kids can be so cruel...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Arthur? We have a problem.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I told you, don't worry. These crane people know what they're doing!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Not that kind of problem.

Speaker: junkie
Dialogue: Phone. And the watch. Hurry.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Um. Out of interest, how did you get up here?

Speaker: junkie
Dialogue: What you talkin' about, dog?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Great. `Picnic in the sky' followed by `Robbed in the sky'!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: OWWW! You don't understand! We're 180 feet up in the sky!

Speaker: junkie
Dialogue: You on the same shit as me, yeah? Good stuff, right?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: No, we're not high! Well we are, but only in the literal sense.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I can't find it. Over here?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: No! That's the bouquet of world hams!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I had fun tonight.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I can't believe I'm saying this, but so did I.

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Summarising Phase Alpha: formal wear for bridal attendants, groom's attendants, mens' formal wear, St John the Divine all confirmed...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Are there breathing holes in the coffin?

Speaker: tailor
Dialogue: I'm sorry?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: In case I'm passed out drunk rather than medically dead?

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Don't worry, Thomas. This whole thing's just a joke to Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Thanks, Hobnobs. You are good to me.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Take this away.  Progress on the reception?

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Black inked at the Emery Roth Room at the Ritz-Carlton.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sorry, everyone. that graphic's too colourful and this hangover's a 7.6 on the Richter..the Sickter...

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Cakes, caterers, floral arrangements, photographer...

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Will there be anything else, sir?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: No, thanks.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Ma'am?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: No. You can leave.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Why all this crap now? What's the rush anyway?

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: The wedding is in a month, Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: A month? I was thinking more sort of ten, fifteen years. Just to really enjoy the anticipation of the big day.

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sorry, Dwight D. Bridalshower, Operation Ball and Chain will have to wait.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Here we are.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: We're not going to end up in the Hudson again, are we?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I can promise you won't get wet.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Are you okay?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Yeah, fine. Actually...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Hey, Richey Rich. Want to go somewhere really romantic?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Everything is 99 cents?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Yip. A whole penny less than those bourgeois assholes at the Dollar Store.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: `Warning: This product contains chromium, which may be linked to chronic bronchitis and reproductive hazards."

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: That one was on the news. Everyone else recalled them, the pussies. Not my 99 Cent!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Maybe China's trying to wipe out the west's children one by one.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Oh, I love this place.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Well, I'd like you to believe it's because I'm a poor girl reduced to buying `Depressed Chef' burgers-in- a-can to Right Said Fred because I don't know where my next paycheck is coming from. But the truth is - bargains get me hot. Got it from ma. Drives my dad crazy. The tour?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Yes please.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Looking west, the ladies' hygiene products. Note that the more natural-sounding the name, e.g. this 'Vermont Breeze' Feminine Spray, the more lethal chemicals it contains. Watch out for the products cunningly labelled to make the dumber consumer think they're getting the real thing: 'Special J', 'Crampbell's Soup', ''Aunt Janina's' Maple-Style Syrup...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Just fascinated.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You're good at fascinated.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You're good at fascinating.

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: Not that one.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: This one?

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: No. There's less beans in it.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: This one?

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: This one?

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: You got a good one here, honey.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Look. Us in a year's time.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I'll get ill.

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Tiger Woods has confirmed!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I didn't know you knew him.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I don't.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Why is he coming?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: He agreed to daddy's fee. This is going to be the happiest day of my life!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: If you can bring Erica, I can bring Hobson.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: She's my wedding planner.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: She's my Hobson.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Tell Naomi. That's an order.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Reminiscent of a French castle perched 500 feet above New York, the penthouse was known from early days as the `Chateau in the Sky'.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: A second ballroom. Obviously. Gotta have a second ballroom.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Where George Gershwin and the Astors danced to Shep Fields and his Rippling Rhythm Orchestra.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I just need one of your collection of bathrooms.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Behind the telephone box fish tank. See you on the balcony.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Hobson?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: He's not like other men, you know.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I think I realised that as I plunged into the Hudson with a junkie. But I like him. He's fun.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I know he is. That's the problem.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I'm sure Arthur will explain.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Your kids' book. What was it about?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: `Vlad the Inhaler'. About an asthmatic boy detective.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Be serious.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Oh, it was dumb. `The Boy Whose Heart Escaped'. It was about this kid who wakes up to find his heart has climbed out and is shinning down the drainpipe to freedom.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I love it.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Rainbow Press said it was too disturbing. But it wasn't literal - there wasn't a kid lying there with a gaping hole in his chest. It was just this cute little heart bouncing up and down shouting `You can't catch me, mofo!'. I'm paraphrasing.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Did he catch the heart?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Never got that far.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Only if I'm sad, happy or bored. There's this bit in a book Hobson used to read me as a kid that says it all: `We must stop eating cookies, Frog!' cried Toad, as he ate another.'

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Frog and Toad! I loved Frog and Toad!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: `Frog put the cookies in a box. `There' he said. Now we will not eat any more cookies.' `But we can open the box.' Frog tied some string around the box. `There' he said, `Now we will not eat any more cookies'. `But we can cut the string and open the box'.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: That was beautiful. It's like you read it yesterday.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I couldn't tell her, Hobson. She isn't the Komodo dragon. She's my toad.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: You're quite sure about this?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Oh, bollocks.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: I don't know, honey. What's this teabag even doing here? Couldn't he make it in Lord of the Rings land?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Not that it matters, but he's a billionaire.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: You have my full permission to marry him.

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: Bravo, Vivienne! Well done!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'd be wary, Grant. She's planning to ride you around the course next. Her last boyfriend broke his ankle jumping that ditch. Had to be destroyed on the spot.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Arthur. What's so urgent that you had to come all the way out here?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm in love. With a woman who isn't exactly who you'd describe as Susan. She's called Naomi.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Arthur, we've been through this!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Won't you at least meet her?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: What family is she from?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: The Snarts of Detroit.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Never heard of them.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: No, because they're normal. She's a walking tour guide, her dad's a retired car worker.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Susan will generate quality sons, not oil-soaked car monkeys.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Unbelievable! Why don't you just keep me here, pay a servant to wank me into a bottle once a day...

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Arthur...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: ...then inject it all into a field of heiresses and see who farts out a thoroughbred first?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: We need an heir!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Fine! You can have one with Stevey Steroids here! Surely even your uterus has had a face lift by now.

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: That's enough, Arthur...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: None of your business, J Crew.

Speaker: grant
Dialogue: You are so ungrateful to your mother. She adores you!

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Arthur. Come back here.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You can shove your inheritance up your horse's arse!

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Suit yourself, Arthur. Follow your heart. But do be aware I consider what you've squandered so far an advance on your inheritance. That's about $17 million.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Why would you do that? You'd never get it back.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: No. But you'd spend the rest of your life in court. There's a simple solution to all this. Marry Susan. And cheat with the nobody from Queens.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Have you been at the cookies?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I ate the whole jar.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Oh, man. What? What?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm engaged. To another Susan. Woman. Engaged to another woman.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: What are you talking about? This is bullshit. Who do you think you are? Is this some rich guy thing?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I was going to tell you! I just...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah, you just.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Please, Naomi! I didn't mean for it to get to this! I planned to just be your friend but then I started to fall for you and I thought `I can't marry Susan, I might fall for Naomi!' But I thought `No I have to marry Susan or I'll be poor so I won't fall for Naomi' But then I did fall for you! Because you're brainy and funny and gorgeous and too smart to do walking tours. You're too smart, Snart. Smart Snart. There's a 99 cent cereal.  Anyway, so I went to see Vivienne, and I said `I can't marry Susan, I love Naomi she's my Frog my Toad' I don't know any more.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You're frog.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Thanks. Then she said `Noooo, if you don't marry Susan, I'll make you pay all the inheritance money back even if you can't - ha ha ha'. Okay she didn't laugh but she might as well have, the evil cow. Because it's like all the money ever and they'll put not just me but both of us in prison and your dad, like in Dickens. There'll be ghosts, and Oliver and....

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Maybe if I'd spotted this facet of your personality earlier we wouldn't be having this conversation.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Toad? Stay a bit longer. Please?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: 'cause it'll reduce the proportion of my life I'll spend feeling utterly miserable.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Bye, Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Bea Arthur? What's she got to do with all this?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: It's going to be okay. I'll get you a beer, yeah?

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: I just have to be alone for a minute...Oh, G-d, I can't bear it...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Designed by William Van Allen and inspired by the machine age of the 1920s, the Chrysler...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Please, interrupt. Hell, who wants to come home with me and butt in with questions while I'm watching Letterman? `Yo. How tall is Dave?'  Sorry, sir. Late night, no sleep, long day. What's your question?

Speaker: female tourist
Dialogue: When I stand here taking every breath with you, ooh...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: What is going on?

Speaker: newsstand guy
Dialogue: And even shared the tears.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Sorry to be a wet blanket, folks. he's getting married. But I guess he didn't choreograph that bit for you.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: But..but this took ages to rehearse. I had the frog outfit specially made. These aren't actual tourists.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I gathered that, Arthur. Are you capable of doing anything without it being a grand gesture?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: It's like Hobson said. You're not like other men. If you were normal, if the money and the booze didn't cloud everything, you'd deal with the fact that you're engaged, rather than just looking for ways to win me back. But it was a lovely routine, really. Fantastic outfit.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I just wanted to see you.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You need to see someone, Arthur. Seriously.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hobson! Female Tom Hanks has had a haircut! Hobson?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: It says here you shouldn't forget to clean your junk. I guess that's what...'genitahlio-ah' is.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Marty? What are you doing there?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Hobson left me in charge. She's gone to bed. She had a headache.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: She's had quite a few headaches lately.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: She blacked out.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Put my bears back on, Arthur.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Not until you answer my question.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I'm travelling down a white tunnel. To - a garden? Mother? Father? Why is it so hot? Who's the red gentleman with the big pitchfork?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Will you cut it out?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Arthur. There are three books. This is important. Take them back to the library...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hobson, please. Don't die any more. It's getting very boring.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Arthur. Old women, like bears, get sore heads. Are you okay? You look a little lost.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Naomi doesn't want to see me.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: A terrible shame she had to go. A little tart like that could have saved you a fortune in prostitutes.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Listen, old woman. Don't ever talk about Naomi that way again. What gives you the right to be such a snob? You're just...you're just... Mary Poppins with a menopause!

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I'm sorry too. You know, Arthur, you may be growing up.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Do you want anything?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I want to be younger.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sorry, it's your job to be older.  Hobson. If you're feeling better tomorrow, will you accompany me somewhere?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Of course, Arthur.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Yes, it would be disastrous to harm such a dignified profile.

Speaker: megan
Dialogue: I was waking up four, five, six mornings a week in different mens' beds...

Speaker: james
Dialogue: I steal from my friends, my family. I sold my son's pedal car so I could score junk...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Jesus....

Speaker: james
Dialogue: I accidentally backed my car over my mother outside Walgreens...

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Marty! This isn't a sports bar in Chicago. These people aren't here to brag.

Speaker: james
Dialogue: I had a business, a home and it's all gone! I'm in this fucking grave and they're pouring the earth in!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Whoooaaahh. Okay, cut. I don't know about anyone else, but this isn't exactly killing my thirst.

Speaker: leader
Dialogue: Well why did you come...What's your name?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Gandalf.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: ...and because I have done nothing with the astonishing opportunities handed to me, apart from pissing away my inheritance and drinking enough to kill a rhino.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's always the quiet ones.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Thanks, Hobson. Maybe you can go every time I crave a drink?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Just promise you'll never ask me to sleep with Susan for you.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Arthur, if that's...  Hello? Yes. Yes, I did...Yes. Sorry? Really? Well I worked pretty hard on it..Love to...Love to...What time?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Good afternoon, Mr Snart. Is Naomi here?

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: You must be the nanny.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I must be.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Well, well.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Ever since I met Arthur I liked him. We have to make sure these two wonderful kids stay together...

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Try not to talk. It's not your words but the breath which bears them. Perhaps you could repair to the East Wing and make me a cup of tea? I wish to speak to Naomi.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Sure, sure.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Arthur is having a pre-wedding party tonight. You should come.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Oh, should I? Are all the other girls he passed up going too?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Don't you want to show Arthur how well you're doing?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Tell him thanks, but I have a deadline.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Arthur doesn't know I'm here. He's far too decent to be involved in something so tawdry. You could bring your father. A magical experience before he's too big to leave this apartment.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Why would I go to this? Why would I do that to myself?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: My dear, if there's one thing old women can tell, it's young men in love. And the food promises to be breathtakingly free.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Are you alright?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Better than you, dear.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You really look out for Arthur, don't you?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Yes. And it is a job that I recommend highly.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Ah, what am I gonna do? The no-kill pet shelter won't take him.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Thank you. Would you go the bathroom and commence washing? You only have three hours and it could be quite a project.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I appreciate what you're trying to do but I'm not going to that party.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Suit yourself.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Have you seen a doctor?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Yes. And he has seen me.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I think Arthur has a very good friend. May I kiss you on the cheek?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Is it something you feel strongly about?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: vocalist
Dialogue: Thanks. We're going to move things up tempo now with `The Only Thing That Looks Good On Me Is You.'

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Splendid affair, Susan.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Don't thank me, thank Erica.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: With all due respect, Hobson, you're talking out of your frumpy English ass. Arthur needs to know!

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: You are not to pull him out of that party on my behalf.  Hello? Naomi!

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: You're gonna get through this, babe. Then who knows what the future may hold?

Speaker: door man
Dialogue: Excuse me, madam. Name? Madam?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Snart plus one.

Speaker: passing woman
Dialogue: Nice dress. Vera Wang?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Ross Dress For Less. You know where Arthur is?

Speaker: passing woman
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: When Arthur proposed to my daughter, I was overjoyous. The Bach-Templemeads are my kind of people: classy. Respectable. Well spoken. People like in Shakespeare in Love, who esprouse the same values I have always upheld both in my business and spiritual life. But tonight isn't about me or America's leading independent formula brand.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Thank you, Burt! I've actually prepared a little surprise song with my friends here.

Speaker: justin
Dialogue: We meet again!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Yeah. Have you seen Arthur?

Speaker: justin
Dialogue: The ballroom. I'll take you to him.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Of course she is. Why would Arthur marry a pig?

Speaker: justin
Dialogue: What business is your family in?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Hm? Oh, I'm the heiress to a fortune built on small pets.

Speaker: justin
Dialogue: I'm sorry?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Hamsters, mice, doglets...

Speaker: justin
Dialogue: Doglets?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Tiny dogs. The technology's not perfect. Seeing a horse the size of a can of soup fall dead before your eyes - that shit stays with you.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Are you sure he's this way?

Speaker: justin
Dialogue: Absolutely.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Excuse me. Have you seen Arthur?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: That way. The ballroom.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Bye, Justin.

Speaker: door man
Dialogue: Excuse me, madam. You're not an authorized guest.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I know that. I'm here to give Arthur some very important news.

Speaker: door man
Dialogue: Of course you are.  Shall we discuss this outside?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Get your hands off me!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's okay, Jeff. She can stay.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Arthur, can I talk to you?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: But what about the other blackouts?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Arthur, I'm fine. Do not leave that party.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: She's fine. They're sending her home. Do you want a drink?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: No, thanks, Arthur. I should go.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: But you came all this way. There's ridiculously fancy food, there's...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Arthur. Please. Can you just call me a cab?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You're a cab.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Orders cabs to take the girls away?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Thank you for coming all this way. I'm sorry for all the stupid presents and calls and gestures.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: It's okay.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What were you like as a kid?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Nuts. I thought the moon followed me. I would walk and think the moon went any place that I did. I thought it meant something special would happen. So I've been waiting. What an ass.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Dance?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Arthur. We've been through this. Call that cab please.

Speaker: mandy miller
Dialogue: To Bombay, a travelling circus came, they brought an intelligent elephant and Nellie was her name...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: What the bejeezus is this?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hobson used to sing it to me.  One dark night, she slipped her iron chain. Off she ran to Hindustan and was never seen again. Nellie the Elephant packed her bags, And said goodbye to the circus, Off she went with a trumpety trump, Trump trump trump...

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Is this the tour guide?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: She's a writer.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Is this the Vivienne?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Crowded field, writing.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Maybe someone will see her potential.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: We all know who's seen her potential.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Meaning?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Oh, of course, you don't know, do you?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Vivienne, please. Don't...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: What is going on here?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: My son became fond of you. You're not the first. Or the last, I imagine. Anyway I was scanning his monthly expenses - which always makes for entertaining reading, all those gifts for all those girls - and found he'd bought an entire publishing company called...what was it now? Rainbow Press.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You bought Rainbow press? So you could tell them to publish my book?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: He knows people, dear. I'm sure you do too, though the people you know tend not to own books, let alone publishers. Arthur, I trust we'll see you back at the party? Susan's a little worried.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: NAOMI! PLEASE! I didn't think I would ever see you again. I was just trying to give you some...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Confidence? Self esteem isn't a gift, Arthur! It isn't a fur coat or a thousand billion orchids or an apartment made from truffles or whatever else you rich freaks use to express love!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I do express love! I love you!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Don't say that!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You just told me to! And stop going on about me being rich! You think it's easy being trapped by money?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Hello, Amnesty? Come quick! Arthur's being held against his will in Guantamoney Bay!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Abu Greed?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Stop riffing with me! How dare you do what you did. I didn't need your money to feel good about myself!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: No. Being cheap gives you that.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: At least I'm prepared to have fun. To live. I'm not all `Oooh look at me with my antique food, aren't I cool?' And...and...your phone's RUBBISH! It's made of bits of old doorbell and vibrator, I bet you can only get calls from 1994 on it!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: As long as I don't get any from a drunk, rich fuck up like you!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Hello? I heard shouting.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I'm an employee of Arthur's. I came to complain about the conditions.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Naomi, please...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Mr Bach-Templemead, I know you thought putting half and half in the staff kitchen was an improvement.  But some people prefer Coffee Mate! You were disrespectful. I quit!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Because you changed the creamer?  Arthur, Marty called from the hospital.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's okay, Hobson's fine. I spoke to her doctor.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Apparently you didn't.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: It's just a headache!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Stop saying that! You bribed a hospital orderly to tell me you were okay!

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Oh, bothersnaps. What do doctors know?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Da dahhhh! I give you the amazing costly, health-giving presents!

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I don't want to put it on.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Put it on. Or I'll fire you.  Okay, or I won't fire you.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: How much did you waste on this poppycock?

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: She sounds like Darth Invader!

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Why, Arthur?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Mr Bach-Templemead? Do you have a moment?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Home? That's great news. Isn't it?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: How did this get here?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: I have no idea.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You might have a brain tumour but you're not a complete veggie burger just yet. Has Naomi been here?

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: She dropped by once or twice. Frightful needy trollop.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I thought she gave up writing.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Just trying to spare her outright humiliation while I'm still here.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Don't wear yourself out. You're not going anywhere soon.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Arthur. I've loved caring for you so much. But you'll never grow up with me around. So either I retire. Or I die. Option 1 involves too much paperwork and blather with having to find somewhere else to live. And no offence to you, dear boy...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: But you spent half of it looking after a spoilt drunk twat.

Speaker: hobson
Dialogue: Exactly. Sorry Arthur. I'm past my use-by date.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sorry, Hobson, You don't win this one. I need you to care for me.  Now take your fish oil.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Hobson?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Would Frog ever get up again? Or would he just sit in his tank, crying and soiling himself until he died of dehydration because he didn't even have the energy to eat a wet sandwich.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: How's the tea?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Shockingly bad, thanks, Marty.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Want to talk about the Cubs game?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Nahhh. Can I be alone please?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Naomi? I doubt you'll ever get this, because your voicemail probably consists of a 4000 year old woman who writes the message down in hieroglyphics then loses it down the back of her incontinence loin cloth. Hobson died. Hobson died and I've fallen apart...

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Arthur! You haven't answered the phone for eight days. Susan's beside herself. What's going on?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What do you think's going on? Hobson died.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Oh, that.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You're comparing Hobson to...a dog?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Well, yes. A faithful, humble companion who...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Um, I think I'd like you to leave, if that's okay. Now?

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Remember who pays for this apartment, Arthur. For everything!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Don't worry. If I'm going to drink myself to death I'll need resources. Bye Vivienne...

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: It's mother!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: My mother's dead.

Speaker: aherne
Dialogue: The last will and testament of Jane Hobson.  `I leave my life savings to the Tulare Bear Sanctuary, Tulare County, California.'

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: That'll explain the strong smell of bear shit. Sorry.

Speaker: aherne
Dialogue: To Arthur Bach Templemead, I leave this.

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: I just want you to know, if he doesn't show up for this wedding, I can't know what I'll do.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Don't worry, Burt. He's cleaned himself up. He's stopped drinking, he's anxious to get a real job. He's become a responsible citizen.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Due to a tragic error in the architect's drawing, the original Statue of Liberty unveiled in 1886 was just seven inches tall. 100,000 New Yorkers rioted, having come expecting to see something more impressive than a garden gnome holding up an ice cream...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Naomi!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Girl's gotta have a dream.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Naomi. Can you take the next 60 years off?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Are you okay? You're a mess. You look like you...now.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sorry. I accidentally swallowed three bottles of hand sanitizer. Fascinating story...Okay.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: I'm so sorry about Hobson.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm sorry about the Rainbow Press.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: It's okay. So how did Susan take it that you're not marrying her?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: She didn't.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You haven't told her?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: What's it to you? She's your arch- enemy.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Are you six? She isn't my enemy. She's the woman you proposed to!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I couldn't tell her! Today's the biggest day of her life!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: The wedding's today? When?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: 12. Which is...  Where's my watch gone?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: It's eight minutes to.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: It's too late, then.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Church?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: St. John the Divine. Can we please just get me some clothes...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: St John..Fourth largest church in the world...111th and Amsterdam. It's about four miles. Better hurry.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You want me to go there? Like this?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: What's the alternative? Jilt Susan at the altar? Can I expect the same treatment when you dump me?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: No! I love you!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: C'mon, folks...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Naomi! Susan's dad will...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Arthur. Prove you're not the same pampered little boy who can have what he wants then toss it aside when he's bored. Then we'll talk.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Naomi! I don't even know the way!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: 5th...right on Broadway...left at Times...Right on 7th...back on Broadway....right on Amsterdam. The church is the big stone pointy thing full of rich people.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: SHIT! TAXI!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: About 15 bucks...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Can anyone spare $15 please?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: What about tip? You cheapskate?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Gather round for the nearly naked Yoga man - YOGI BARE! I give you...

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: A block and a half.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: GO!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Excuse me, are there trains down there, like in films?

Speaker: passerby
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Excuse me. Terribly sorry to bother you, but...

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: ...originally a rough neighbourhood. Some say it was called 42nd Street because it wasn't safe to spend more than forty seconds on it.

Speaker: male tourist
Dialogue: Excuse me.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: If you burst into song, you're off this bus.

Speaker: male tourist
Dialogue: Huh? I want to see St. John the Divine.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Sorry, sir, that's not on our route today. Anyway...

Speaker: female tourist
Dialogue: I want to know if Arthur's gonna make it.

Speaker: male tourist
Dialogue: It says here `ask about your personalised tours'. I want the personalised tour. To St. John the Divine!

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Okay!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Ah! I'm trying to get to...

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Uh, unit 6J, we have reports of an indecent exposure on a school bus.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'm not him.  Look ma! No holes.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Arthur? What's going on?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Susan. I can't...I can't...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: The girl at the party? The one who talked all that rubbish about Coffee Mate? I love her.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Shut up! We're getting married!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: But I don't love you!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: And you think I love you?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Well, yes. What's not to...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: I never have.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Susan, you're upset, you hate me. It's okay. Now I'm sorry, I have to go, or your dad's going to do whatever he did to your boyfriend from college.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Daddy never hurt Alex. He paid her parents to send her away..

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: HER? You're..a...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Lesbian. Yes. You may have noticed that daddy is homophobic. He swore he'd disown me if it happened again.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: But...why do you want to marry...

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Why else do you think I'd spend more than 30 seconds in your company? You're the perfect cover.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Have you been pretending to like Dane Cook as well?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Wow. Wow. Well. Uh...  Thanks for your honesty. I don't feel so bad about calling this off.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Arthur, please. You can drink as much as you like, sneak off to Naomi. We keep the money. We live our lives. Everyone wins.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I may be a weak, pathetic drunk. But I won't marry a lesbian Dane Cook fan.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Good evening, St. John the Divine! Anyone in from St. Patrick's? Bialystoker Synagogue? Manhattan Mosque? AA?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: ...and the first turned to the second horse and said `That dog just spoke'.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Daddy, no! Stop it!

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Burt! Get off my son!

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: DADDY!!!

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: You wouldn't hurt me.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Wouldn't I? You crushed me.

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: I just wanted you to be happy.

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Bullshit. You wanted to stop me being a lesbian!

Speaker: burt
Dialogue: Shut up! Shut up you dirty little dyke harlot!

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: You want some more, bitch? Huh?

Speaker: susan
Dialogue: Erica, that's enough, honey.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Why didn't you tell me? We could have worked something out.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: OW! Stop it! Why are you doing that?

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: Because I hate an infection! Keep still.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: No, you keep still.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: What are we going to do, Arthur?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I'll get a job. I'll model cheap riding boots for people with no horses. You can write books about boys whose lungs have run away.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Stop this!

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sorry, Vivienne. I can't do that.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: I beg your pardon?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: You've never earned that title. I wouldn't fake it with Susan. I won't with you.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Arthur. I will withdraw this offer forever. Don't doubt me, boy.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I don't.

Speaker: vivienne
Dialogue: Arthur! Arthur! I am serious! If you walk out of that door...

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Sorry, Marty. This isn't mine any more. Fancy joining us for a bowl of Special J?

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Operational heat controls in a shower are a basic human right!

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: Package for you. With any luck an apartment for you and Lurch.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: I thought you liked me.

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: I may have been seduced by money. It happens.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: `Can I be your friend at least? Love, Vivienne xxx. P.S. Lunch sometime? P.P.S. The inheritance is yours. It always was.'

Speaker: ralph
Dialogue: On balance, I'd go for it.

Speaker: marty
Dialogue: Money good.

Speaker: naomi
Dialogue: You were never happy rich, honey. It's only been a month. Be strong. Remember: however hard life gets, love will always find a way.

Speaker: arthur
Dialogue: Brought her for moral support. But I'll do the talking this time.
